h2.strong: Tools, sources, and product components visibility rules

p.span: Use these rules to establish the content's placement in the KB. For example, if the issue verification requires access to curator_cli, the article must be made internal. On the other hand, if the Description section does not rely on internal tools, but the solution or a workaround requires editing gflags, move the solution or the workaround to Internal comments instead and recommend contacting Nutanix Support.

li.span: Links to other Nutanix internal articles
Product source code (Sourcegraph outputs, for example)
Service pages (stargate/curator, http:localhost:2009). Read-only pages where specific guidance is provided on the usage and interpretation of output
Static URLs to partner or major vendor resources (Microsoft, VMware, Hyper-V), where they directly relate to a Nutanix issue that helps resolve/describe the issue
Use the present tense and active voice
Instead of “a reseat can be performed as part of troubleshooting”, say “reseat [the node]”
Instead of “the logs will contain” say “the logs contain [the following error messages]”
Avoid jargon, metaphors, and unnecessary words. Examples include:
Cluster thinks, needs, searches. Define the process or requirements instead.
It has been observed that – redundant, explain the issue instead
Avoid using “please”. The purpose of the KB article is to instruct, not ask.
to help you organise content within the article
Use accurate and current product names (e.g., “SATADOM”, not “SATA DOM”). Use the
as a reference and standard. For terms not included there, use the vendor's official documentation as a reference.
When listing a KB number, use a hyphen "-" between "KB" and the number, for example, KB-1540.
Tags must reflect only what is present in the
Avoid negative terms like “bug,” “crash,” “panic”, “stuck”. Use “issue”, “failure”, “program halt”, “no progress”, “abort”.

No personal identifiable information (PII) such as names (including hosts, VM, servers), email addresses, IP addresses, UUIDs, serial numbers, in text, code blocks, or images, regardless of their source (lab, customer environment, or else).
